Get Into Phyco¶

What is Phyco?¶

Phyco is a developing physics engine implemented mainly in Python 3. For now, it supports to 3-D multi mass point simulation in various types of force field. Collision detectection is finished and tested somehow, but supports only 2-body collision. Further developing is in progress.

Though Phyco are to be a physics engine, it supports not only physics manipulations, that is, building it calls not only for physics formulas and programming skills. Phyco also integrated a fairly adequate math processor, with capability to:

  • Process symbolic math expressions;
  • Do vector manipulations;
  • Do some operation such as compute determinant of matrices;
  • Do differentiation to elementary functions.

Alongside with math, Phyco do pattern match by Aho-Corasick Algorithm, in both expression handling and aliasing feature.

Something to know about Phyco~¶

Phyco is originally written in Python 3.4 and diverted to 3.5, and is reforming to integrate C++ extensions for better performance.

Written in Python, Phyco inherits Python PEP 20 and some other spirits and mottos of Python, and is highly Object-Oriented. Besides, Phyco takes flexiblity as the first. Using Phyco do not require knowledge in programming (Ugh, little maybe), but there’s a few conventions or terms used in this document that would be confusing if without Python background.

  • Anything you will see in Phyco can be generally called as Object without specifying its type.
  • class as a qualifier can be thought as a category of objects or a type of objects.
  • All self in documents refers the object itself.

Phyco Structure¶

The top level of Phyco (User Interface, UI) is command line (shell), which you use to send command. A valid Phyco command can have only one verb which is at the beginning of the command. Knowing this is enough for using Phyco, but you’re welcomed to be curious about what will be done inside Phyco. (You’re recommended to try using Phyco before seeing the following.)

Every input of yours are firstly translated to python code. (This is not so good though.) Any Object you created are stored in a dict. You may have tried to either set a property of an object or create an object with a property embeded in initially. This is achieved by setting attributes of your object.

As you start a sim, a lot of things are done, and this might be the core of Phyco. pass!

Types in Phyco¶

Types is something fundamental in Phyco. Everything encountered should have a type. It seems awkward for new comers that a few words like type, class or object are introduced. But you just feel free to use it just in everyday you do. In Phyco, here’s a few types of modules, namely:

  • Mechanics Types: object, constraint
  • Sim Types: simulation, event
  • LinAlg Types: vector, matrix, field
  • Geom Types: Under Construction
  • ... (more in Phyco but you won’t meet them so soon)

But it’s never necessary for you to remember which specific type belongs to which module, it’s auto completed in Phyco anytime once needed. You can also find specific help doc to know them better.
